title: Summary of Important News Items and Editorials-45
content: INDIAN EXPRESS DATED 23 RD JULY 2025. 1. Dhankhar Accepting Opposition Notice to Impeach Judge Rubbed Govt the Wrong Way Vice-President Jagdeep Dhankhar’s unexpected acceptance of the Opposition’s motion to impeach Justice Yashwant Varma of the Allahabad High Court reportedly irked the Union Government. The Centre was preparing a similar motion in the Lok Sabha, hoping for bipartisan consensus to claim moral authority. However, the Opposition submitted its notice first in the Rajya Sabha, excluding NDA members to retain the anti-corruption plank. Dhankhar’s announcement of the notice led to confusion and a scramble by the government to gather signatures. The government's unease deepened when Dhankhar referred to a pending motion against Justice Shekhar Yadav and earlier allegations of misconduct in Parliament. The Vice-President’s resignation soon after—citing health reasons—sparked speculation, particularly as key ministers skipped a scheduled meeting with him. The episode reflects deepening tensions between the presiding officer and the government, with procedural decisions influencing political outcomes during a charged Monsoon Session. 2. 7/11 Mumbai Blasts: Pressure Cooker Theory Dismantled in Court The Bombay High Court’s acquittal of all 12 accused in the 2006 Mumbai train blasts case marked a major setback to the prosecution’s theory. Central to the case was the claim that bombs were hidden in pressure cookers placed on luggage racks. However, the court found significant flaws—witnesses lacked credibility and no Test Identification Parades were conducted. A key shopkeeper's testimony regarding the sale of cookers was deemed irrelevant due to lack of procedural corroboration. Forensic reports revealed the recovered parts were not from original Kanchan cookers. The bench also noted the improbability of passengers recalling standard-size bags used in crowded local trains. The ruling underscores the dangers of relying on circumstantial and unverified evidence in terror trials. The judgment not only dismantled a long-standing theory but also highlighted procedural lapses and insufficient investigative rigor in a case that had deeply impacted Mumbai’s collective psyche. 3. SC Allows CBI to Register 22 Cases in Bank-Builder Nexus to Cheat Homebuyers In a major intervention to protect homebuyers, the Supreme Court allowed the CBI to file 22 regular FIRs in cases alleging a nexus between banks and builders in NCR cities like Noida and Gurugram. Thousands of buyers, who had opted for subvention plans, were compelled to repay EMIs without getting possession of their homes. The SC acknowledged a prima facie case against banks and developers like Supertech and ordered full investigations, noting that CBI had already conducted extensive preliminary enquiries. The court also expressed concern over coercive orders from Gurugram trial courts and directed the district judge to investigate these. Additionally, it asked the CBI to consider inputs from amicus curiae Rajiv Jain for enhancing transparency in authorities like RERA. The judgment reinforces the judiciary’s proactive role in real estate frauds and signals tighter scrutiny over systemic financial exploitation of common citizens. 4. Delhi Raises Olympic Gold Cash Prize to ₹7 Crore, Offers Government Jobs to Medallists The Delhi government announced a substantial increase in cash incentives for Olympic and Paralympic medallists—raising gold rewards to ₹7 crore—and introduced job reservations under its revamped sports policy. This move aligns Delhi with states like Haryana and Odisha in recognizing sporting excellence. The new Mukhyamantri Khel Protsahan Yojana offers structured government jobs: Group A for Olympic gold/silver winners, and lower groups for other medallists, including at Asian, CWG, and national levels. Financial support is also extended to students performing at national and state competitions. In tandem, the government approved a laptop distribution scheme for top-performing Class 10 students and sanctioned ICT labs for Delhi’s schools, acknowledging a longstanding infrastructure gap. By linking sports success to employment and education, Delhi aims to build a more robust ecosystem encouraging youth participation in athletics, while also addressing digital access and academic support among school students. 5. Traffic Overhaul Planned for NDLS, IGI Airport & ITO in Delhi The New Delhi Municipal Council and Delhi Traffic Police have initiated a major traffic management overhaul at three critical city zones: New Delhi Railway Station, Indira Gandhi International Airport, and ITO. These hotspots are notorious for congestion, pedestrian confusion, and unregulated vehicular flow. The initiative aims to streamline multi-modal transport, ease pedestrian crossings, and decongest arterial roads through realignment of signals, introduction of holding areas, and stricter enforcement. At IGI, focus is on integrating airport cabs and ride-shares, while ITO may see better lane management and re-routing of buses. The plan includes modern traffic monitoring infrastructure and possibly smart camera-based enforcement. These areas are not only high footfall zones but also symbolic of Delhi’s logistical and civic challenges. The reforms are expected to facilitate smoother transit and reflect the city’s ambition to prepare for future population growth, events, and global connectivity. 6. A Bridge to London – India-UK FTA Cleared by Cabinet The Indian Cabinet has approved the long-pending Free Trade Agreement (FTA) with the United Kingdom, paving the way for Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s upcoming London visit. The finalized text of the deal is expected to be released soon. This FTA, under negotiation since Brexit, addresses tariff reductions, market access, investment rules, and digital trade. It is especially significant as it marks India's first major bilateral trade pact with a Western nation post-COVID. The agreement will offer easier access for Indian goods like textiles, automotive parts, and pharmaceuticals to UK markets, while also liberalizing visa rules and education mobility for Indian professionals and students. For the UK, access to India’s growing consumer base and fintech sector is a key gain. This agreement reflects India’s strategic realignment of trade policy towards bilateralism, aimed at economic diversification, employment growth, and geostrategic balancing amid global disruptions. 7. Why He Resigned – Editorial Insight on Dhankhar’s Exit The editorial "Why He Resigned" delves into the political and institutional undercurrents surrounding Vice-President Jagdeep Dhankhar’s abrupt resignation. Though officially attributed to health concerns, the resignation follows a fraught session in the Rajya Sabha, where Dhankhar accepted the Opposition’s impeachment motion against a sitting judge before the government could act. The editorial suggests this procedural neutrality clashed with the government's expectations of loyalty, reflecting deeper frictions between constitutional offices and executive authority. It also underscores Dhankhar’s pattern of occasionally asserting institutional independence despite being perceived as aligned with the ruling dispensation. His exit thus marks a critical moment in the evolving power dynamics between Parliament’s presiding officers and the government, raising questions about the scope of autonomy and procedural fairness in highly polarized political climates. The editorial calls for introspection on the part of both government and Opposition to preserve the sanctity of democratic institutions. 8. Clearing the Air on Coal – Explainer on Coal Policy and Environmental Concerns This piece explains recent developments in India’s coal sector in light of environmental and economic debates. Despite its commitment to net- zero emissions by 2070, India remains heavily reliant on coal to meet rising energy demands. The government’s latest policy seeks to balance energy security with environmental obligations by allowing captive and commercial mining, while also investing in cleaner technologies like coal gasification. Critics argue that such dual strategies create regulatory confusion and delay the shift to renewables. However, policymakers maintain that coal will remain critical for base-load requirements in the short-to-medium term. The explainer contextualizes this approach against India’s industrial growth, infrastructure needs, and rural electrification goals. It also highlights the international scrutiny India faces in global climate forums. Ultimately, the article underscores the challenge of phasing down rather than phasing out coal—a nuanced stance reflecting India’s developmental and climate realities. 9. China Breaks Ground on $170-Bn Dam Near Arunachal; India Concerned China’s construction of a $170 billion mega-dam near the Yarlung Tsangpo River, close to Arunachal Pradesh, has triggered strategic alarm in India. The dam—reportedly set to be one of the world’s largest—may potentially divert water from the Brahmaputra, a crucial river for India’s northeast. Though China claims the project is for hydropower and flood control, India fears it could impact downstream water availability and be used as leverage in future conflicts. The lack of a water-sharing treaty between the two nations exacerbates these concerns. Indian experts also worry about ecological consequences and the dam's structural integrity in a seismically active region. The development comes amid ongoing border tensions and adds another layer to Sino-Indian rivalry. India is expected to raise the issue diplomatically and accelerate its own hydropower and river management projects in the northeast to counter any strategic disadvantage. 10. National Sports Governance Bill to Bring BCCI Under Oversight The government is set to introduce the National Sports Governance Bill, which will bring all National Sports Federations (NSFs)—including the BCCI—under a unified oversight framework. Though BCCI receives no state funding, the bill mandates all federations to register with a National Sports Board, adhere to age and tenure limits, and be subject to Right to Information (RTI) provisions. It also proposes the creation of a National Sports Tribunal for dispute resolution. While the BCCI has historically resisted external oversight, citing its autonomy, the new framework seeks to enhance transparency and athlete welfare, particularly as India prepares to bid for the 2036 Olympics. The bill reflects the Centre’s push for cleaner, accountable governance in sports amid international pressure from bodies like the IOC. It also balances autonomy with accountability, ensuring that elite federations contribute to national objectives without becoming law unto themselves. content: Tax News-5 (on the basis  cases uploaded in August 2025) Estimation of Profit in Sahara Land Dealings Restricted to 20% and Additions Based on Loose Papers/Notional Interest Deleted Ashish Prafulbhai Patel v. DCIT [2025 (8) TMI 754 - ITAT Ahmedabad] In this case, the assessee, acting as a mediator in land transactions for Sahara City Homes of Sahara India Commercial Corporation Ltd. (SICCL), was subjected to search proceedings. Evidence showed his role was that of facilitator, with payments made at Sahara’s instance. The Assessing Officer estimated profit at 20% based on a letter, while the assessee claimed lower margins. The Tribunal upheld estimation at 20%, noting seized material corroborated profit margin. It held once income is estimated, further disallowances under Sections 40A(3) or 37(1) are unwarranted. On unexplained expenditure, telescoping against disclosed income was allowed. Interest income noted in seized documents was taxed in the current year, but additions for notional interest and unexplained cash deposits were deleted as unsupported by evidence. Additions solely based on loose papers without corroboration were also struck down. Thus, income was to be recomputed on 20% profit estimation while unwarranted additions were deleted. Genuineness of Share Sale to Arrow Upheld; Section 68 Addition Deleted and Exemption u/ss 11 & 12 Restored A.C.I.T. (Exemption) v. Dr. K.R. Shroff Foundation & Dr. K.R. Shroff Foundation v. D.C.I.T. [2025 (8) TMI 755 - ITAT Ahmedabad] In this case, the assessee, a charitable trust registered u/s 12AA, received 80 lakh shares of e-Infochips Ltd. as corpus donation from its trustee, which were later sold to Arrow Electronics India Pvt. Ltd. for ₹538.40 crores. The Assessing Officer treated the transaction as a colourable device, adding the amount u/s 68 as unexplained cash credit and also denied exemption u/s 11 & 12 by invoking section 13(1)(c). The ITAT held that the sale was genuine since over 500 shareholders, including a Gujarat Government entity, sold shares at the same price, and Arrow’s funding from its Mauritius holding company was duly explained. Relying on Vodafone International Holdings BV v. UOI (SC), the Tribunal rejected Revenue’s doubts on source and creditworthiness. Further, as none of the conditions under section 13(2) applied, donation of shares by trustee could not be treated as a benefit to him. The ITAT deleted the addition under section 68 and restored exemption u/s 11 & 12, holding the trust’s activities as charitable in nature. Transfer Taxable in AY 2014–15; Section 43CA Addition in AY 2015–16 Unsustainable Navketan Premises Pvt. Ltd. v. DCIT [2025 (8) TMI 756 - ITAT Mumbai] The assessee, a real estate developer, sold four commercial units in “Hi-Life Mall,” Santacruz, Mumbai, on 13.07.2013, receiving full consideration through banking channels and handing over possession. The income was offered to tax in AY 2014–15. However, the AO sought to tax the difference between stated sale consideration and stamp duty value under section 43CA in AY 2015–16, relying on the later registration date and DVO valuation of 03.05.2015. The Tribunal held that once possession and payment were completed in July 2013, the transfer was concluded under section 2(47)(v) read with section 53A of the Transfer of Property Act. Registration at a later stage was merely procedural and could not defer taxability. Since the income had already been taxed in AY 2014–15, taxing it again in AY 2015–16 violated consistency and finality principles. The DVO valuation was found irrelevant. Accordingly, the ITAT deleted the ₹3.56 crore addition under section 43CA and allowed the assessee’s appeal. Top of Form Additions Based Solely on Sworn Statement or Third-Party Records Held Unsustainable; Deletion of Unaccounted Deposits, Loans, Interest, and Cash Confirmed Bottom of Form DCIT v. No. 1 Auto Finance & Helpline Motor Finance [2025 (8) TMI 757 - ITAT Chennai] In this case, additions were made on account of alleged unaccounted deposits, interest, loans, and unexplained cash solely on the basis of a sworn statement of the assessee’s managing partner and certain third-party records. The ITAT held that such additions were unsustainable as the Revenue failed to produce any corroborative evidence such as ledgers, recipient confirmations, or independent material to prove the alleged deposits or interest payments. It reiterated the settled law that mere statements during search without supporting evidence cannot justify additions under section 153A for non-abated years. Similarly, additions based on an excel sheet found at a third party’s premises, without identifying lenders or borrowers, were deleted following CIT v. Sant Lal [2020 (3) TMI 692 - Delhi HC]. Regarding unexplained cash, the reconciliation furnished by the assessee was neither disproved nor found false by the AO, and since book balance exceeded physical cash, addition was unwarranted. The Tribunal upheld the CIT(A)’s deletion of both substantive and protective additions, deciding fully in favour of the assessee. Revaluation Proceeds Not Taxable u/s 28(iv); Reopening Void for Lack of Reasons ITO v. Damayanti Ramachandran (HUF) [2025 (8) TMI 758 - ITAT Chennai] In this case, the assessee HUF received additional profit share on account of revaluation of goodwill during reconstitution of a partnership firm. The AO treated the credited goodwill as taxable income u/s 28(iv). The Tribunal, however, held that section 28(iv) applies only to non-monetary benefits or perquisites, not to monetary receipts. Relying on Mahindra & Mahindra [2018 (5) TMI 358 - SC], it observed that revaluation proceeds credited and withdrawn by partners cannot be taxed as business perquisites. It further held that since the reconstitution was effected through a family arrangement among partners of the same family, it could not be termed a mere business arrangement as claimed by Revenue. Therefore, the CIT(A)’s deletion of the addition was upheld. On reopening of assessment u/s 147, the Tribunal found that the AO failed to record valid reasons, did not supply them to the assessee, and merely made vague references in notices. Citing GKN Driveshafts (India) Ltd. [2002 (11) TMI 7 - SC] and Kavee Enterprises (P.) Ltd. [2007 (9) TMI 219 - Jharkhand HC], it held that non-communication of reasons strikes at the root of jurisdiction, rendering reassessment orders void. Accordingly, assessee’s appeal was allowed and Revenue’s appeal dismissed.Top of Form Additions on Undisclosed Profit, Other Sources, and Capital Gain Remanded for Verification Shri Kishore Mohanlal Dingra v. DDIT [2025 (8) TMI 759 - ITAT Mumbai] In this case, the assessee’s appeal concerned multiple additions made by the AO for AY 2016–17. First, the AO had added ₹14.92 lakh as undisclosed business profit by applying a net profit rate of 32.87% on alleged unexplained turnover based on cash deposits. The ITAT noted that the assessee had provided a fresh working of such deposits showing no positive undisclosed profit. Since this required verification, the issue was remanded to the AO for reconsideration. Secondly, an addition of ₹31.03 lakh under “income from other sources” was made in respect of four unexplained credit entries. The assessee furnished fresh explanations with documents before the Tribunal. As these were not examined earlier, this issue too was restored to the AO for fresh adjudication. Thirdly, on the issue of long-term capital gain of ₹6.94 lakh arising from cancellation of a flat booking at Chembur, Mumbai, the assessee produced builder confirmations for the first time. This matter was also sent back to the AO for verification. The addition of ₹52,361/- for interest income was not pressed by the assessee. The grounds on charging of interest u/ss 234A and 234B were held consequential. Thus, the appeal was allowed for statistical purposes, with all major issues remanded to the AO for fresh decision after due opportunity to the assessee. Top of Form 7. Disallowance u/s 14A and Addition u/s 43CA Deleted; Forex Fluctuation Issue Remanded; Carry Forward of LTCL Denied Bennett, Coleman & Co. Ltd. v. DCIT [2025 (8) TMI 760 – ITAT Mumbai] In this appeal, multiple issues concerning disallowances and additions came up for adjudication. The first pertained to section 14A, where the assessee had already disallowed ₹35.01 lakh towards expenditure relatable to exempt income. However, the Assessing Officer, without recording the mandatory dissatisfaction, invoked Rule 8D and made an additional disallowance of ₹21.31 crore. The Tribunal held that in the absence of such satisfaction, the disallowance was invalid and directed its deletion. The second issue arose under section 43CA, where the difference between actual sale consideration and stamp duty valuation of a property was ₹17.46 lakh, falling within the permissible tolerance margin of 10%. Relying on the precedent of John Flower India Ltd. , the ITAT deleted this addition as well. The third issue concerned foreign exchange fluctuation on redemption of preference shares by an overseas subsidiary, where notional entries under AS-11 had been booked. Since factual verification was lacking, the Tribunal restored the matter to the AO for fresh examination. Finally, the assessee’s claim of carry forward of long-term capital loss on STT-paid shares was rejected, with the Tribunal upholding the reasoning of the CIT(A) that such claims were not permissible. Overall, the appeal was partly allowed: the section 14A and 43CA additions were deleted, the forex difference issue was remanded, while the disallowance of carry forward of capital loss was confirmed. 8. Addition u/s 56(2)(viib) on Share Premium Deleted; Depreciation on Hospital Management Rights Allowed DCIT v. Max Hospitals and Allied Services Ltd. [2025 (8) TMI 761 – ITAT Mumbai] In this case, the Revenue challenged two major issues: addition of share premium under section 56(2)(viib) and disallowance of depreciation on a non-refundable deposit treated as an intangible asset. The assessee had issued equity shares at a premium based on the Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) method as certified by a Chartered Accountant. The AO rejected the valuation, pointing out that the projections did not match actual performance and that the assessee was loss-making at the relevant time. However, both the CIT(A) and the Tribunal held that as per section 56(2)(viib) read with Rule 11UA, an assessee is entitled to adopt either DCF or NAV method, and once a prescribed expert’s valuation is relied upon, the AO cannot substitute his own assessment of value. The ITAT further relied on Cinestaan Entertainment (P) Ltd. [2019 (6) TMI 1367 – ITAT Delhi] as affirmed by the Delhi High Court, which held that valuation based on projections cannot be rejected merely because actual results later differ. Accordingly, the deletion of the ₹10.73 crore addition was upheld. The second issue related to depreciation claimed on a non-refundable deposit of ₹25 crore paid for acquiring operation and management rights of Nanavati Hospital. The assessee treated this payment as acquisition of intangible rights eligible for depreciation under section 32(1)(ii). The AO denied depreciation on the grounds that it was conditional and refundable. The CIT(A) noted that depreciation had already been allowed in earlier years, and therefore could not be disallowed in subsequent years, especially since the rights acquired constituted intangible assets. Relying on Bangalore International Airport Ltd. [2022 (11) TMI 318 – Karnataka HC], which recognized such rights as transferable intangible assets, the ITAT confirmed that depreciation was allowable. Thus, the Tribunal dismissed all Revenue’s appeals, holding that valuation under DCF method cannot be interfered with by the AO, and that non-refundable deposits conferring business rights qualify as intangible assets eligible for depreciation. Penalty u/s 272A(1)(d cancelled due to lack of service of notices on NRI assessee Jayshree Nilam Patel v. ITO [2025 (8) TMI 762 – ITAT Ahmedabad] In this case, the issue concerned imposition of penalty under section 272A(1)(d) of the Income-tax Act, 1961, for failure to comply with notices issued under section 142(1). The assessee, a non-resident Indian residing abroad for the past thirty years, had not filed her return of income for AY 2017–18. Based on information from a search in the Navratna Group and subsequent disclosure before the ITSC regarding unaccounted on-money in real estate transactions, her case was reopened under section 147. Notices under sections 148A(b), 148, and 142(1) were issued, but according to the assessee, none were effectively served. She first became aware of the proceedings only upon receiving a demand notice under section 156 via email in November 2023. The Assessing Officer, treating her as non-cooperative, made an addition of ₹3.17 crore under section 69 and imposed a penalty of ₹20,000 under section 272A(1)(d). The CIT(A) confirmed the penalty, holding that non-compliance with multiple statutory notices justified its levy. However, the ITAT noted that no material was produced by the Revenue to show that proper service of notices was made in accordance with law, especially considering the assessee’s NRI status. Importantly, even the CIT(A) in quantum proceedings had restored the matter to the AO for de novo consideration, suggesting a lack of effective communication. The Tribunal emphasized that penalty under section 272A(1)(d) requires proof of willful default, which was absent here. The non-compliance was attributable to lack of service and knowledge, not deliberate defiance. Penalizing an assessee for a default beyond her awareness would be unjust. Accordingly, the ITAT cancelled the penalty and allowed the appeal. Depreciation on goodwill wrongly allowed – Revision u/s 263 upheld as AO failed to apply consistency with earlier disallowance Unique Mercantile India Ltd. v. PCIT [2025 (8) TMI 763 – ITAT Ahmedabad] In this case, the Principal Commissioner of Income Tax (PCIT) exercised revisionary powers under section 263 of the Income-tax Act, 1961, against the assessment order for AY 2018–19. The PCIT found that the Assessing Officer (AO) had allowed depreciation of ₹57.11 crores on goodwill, even though the same claim had been disallowed in the immediately preceding year (AY 2017–18). The PCIT observed that goodwill had been wrongly shown under the “Building” block at 5% depreciation, though it was an intangible asset, and there was no change in facts or law to justify a different treatment in the current year. The assessee argued that since depreciation had been allowed in subsequent years without objection, the principle of consistency should protect its claim. However, the Tribunal rejected this contention, noting that consistency applies when a claim is accepted year after year without objection, not when the same claim was disallowed in the first year itself and then wrongly allowed later. The allowance of an incorrect claim in later years could not justify its allowance in the current year. The Tribunal also emphasized that the AO had not conducted any meaningful inquiry into the depreciation claim despite clear grounds for disallowance, making the order erroneous and prejudicial to the Revenue. Accordingly, the ITAT upheld the PCIT’s order under section 263, affirming that the AO’s failure to disallow depreciation on goodwill in AY 2018–19, despite earlier disallowance and no change in facts, justified revision. content: IT Act 2025-2 CHAPTER XVI PROCEDURE FOR ASSESSMENT A.—Procedure for assessment ------------------------------------------------- (1) Analysis of section 268 1. Purpose of Section 268: This section deals with the powers of the Assessing Officer (AO) when examining a taxpayer’s return. It allows the AO to ask for returns, documents, and other information, and also provides procedures for special audits and inventory valuations if required. 2. Power to Issue Notice (Sub-section 1): Sub-section (1) authorises the AO to serve a notice on any person who has either filed a return under Section 263 or whose time limit for filing such return has expired. The notice may require the assessee to perform specific acts—such as furnishing a return of income (if not already filed), producing accounts and documents specified, or furnishing information in writing, including a statement of assets and liabilities. The liability of the AO is to ensure that the notice clearly mentions the requirements and allows reasonable time for compliance. The assessee, on the other hand, is obliged to furnish the return, documents, or statements demanded, thereby placing an affirmative duty on him to disclose information relevant to his tax liability. In brief, The AO can send a notice to: i. Any person who has filed a return under Section 263 , or ii. Any person who has not filed a return within the time allowed. The notice may require the person: (a) To file a return if not already filed. (b) To produce accounts or documents as required. (c) To provide written information (including a statement of all assets and liabilities , even those not in books of account). 3. Restrictions and Safeguards (Sub-section 2 & 3): Sub-section (2), places safeguards on the AO’s authority under sub-section (1). The AO cannot demand information on assets and liabilities not recorded in the books unless he has obtained prior approval of the Joint Commissioner. Similarly, the AO is barred from requiring production of accounts for periods earlier than three years before the relevant assessment year. The duty cast upon the AO is therefore one of restraint and due process—he must act within these boundaries. For the assessee, this means he is only required to comply with lawful requisitions that satisfy these safeguards. Sub-section (3) provides that not only the AO but also another prescribed authority may issue the notice referred to in sub-section (1)(a). The duty of the AO or prescribed authority is to ensure proper service of such notice. The liability of the assessee remains to comply with the notice irrespective of the issuing authority, as long as it is legally competent to issue it. In brief, The AO needs prior approval of the Joint Commissioner before asking for a statement of all assets and liabilities outside the books. AO cannot demand records older than 3 years from the relevant tax year. The notice under 268(1)(a) can also be issued by a prescribed income-tax authority . 4. AO’s Power to Inquire (Sub-section 4): Sub-section (4) gives the AO discretion to make further inquiries to elicit complete information regarding the income or loss of the assessee. The liability imposed on the AO is to use this discretion judiciously and only to the extent necessary for assessment. The assessee, conversely, must respond truthfully and provide clarifications or evidence when such inquiry is undertaken. In brief, the AO may conduct any inquiry considered necessary to gather complete information about the taxpayer’s income or loss. 5. Special Audit / Inventory Valuation (Sub-sections 5 to 7): Sub-section (5) provides that where accounts are complex, voluminous, doubtful, involve multiple transactions, or relate to specialised nature of business, the AO may direct the assessee to have the accounts audited or the inventory valued. However, the AO’s duty is conditional—he must first obtain prior approval of higher authorities (Principal Commissioner/Chief Commissioner, etc.) and also provide the assessee with a reasonable opportunity of being heard before issuing such a direction. The assessee’s liability here is to arrange for the audit or valuation through the professional nominated and submit the report in the prescribed form. Sub-section (6) provides that the nomination of the accountant or cost accountant is the responsibility of the Commissioner/Principal Commissioner or equivalent authority, not the AO himself. Thus, the AO is bound to act on such nomination. The assessee’s duty is to cooperate with the professional so nominated and provide necessary access to books, records, or inventory. Sub-section (7) makes it clear that the powers of the AO under sub-section (5) can be exercised even if the assessee’s accounts have already been audited under any other law, such as the Companies Act. The liability of the assessee is therefore to comply with such further audit or valuation without objection on the ground that a previous audit has been conducted. In brief, if the AO finds that- i.Accounts complex or voluminous, ii.Doubts in correctness of accounts, iii. Too many transactions, iv. Specialised nature of business, then, with prior approval of higher authority and after hearing the taxpayer, AO may direct the assessee: (i) To get accounts audited by an accountant. (ii) To get inventory valued by a cost accountant. Important points : i. The accountant/cost accountant is nominated by the Commissioner /Principal Commissioner. This applies even if the assessee’s accounts are already audited under some other law. 6. Time Limit for Audit/Valuation Reports (Sub-sections 8–10): These sub-sections provide that the AO is required to fix a period within which the assessee must furnish the audit or valuation report. He may extend the period on sufficient cause being shown, but the total period including extensions cannot exceed six months from the end of the month in which the direction was issued. This provision casts a liability on the AO to monitor deadlines and exercise discretion in granting extensions. For the assessee, the obligation is to ensure timely submission of the report within the prescribed or extended period. In brief, i. The assessee must submit the audit/valuation report within the period specified by AO. AO can extend the period for good reason, but the total period (original + extension) cannot exceed 6 months from the end of the month when the direction was issued. 7. Expenses of Audit/Valuation (Sub-section 11): Sub-section (11) provides that the liability for meeting expenses, including remuneration of the nominated professional, lies with the Central Government and not the assessee. The AO’s duty is to ensure that the expenses are determined in accordance with the guidelines issued by the Commissioner. For the assessee, this provision serves as relief—he is not financially burdened for complying with an audit or valuation directed by the AO. In brief, expenses, including accountant’s fees, will be decided by the Commissioner and paid by the Central Government, not the taxpayer. 8. Right of Assessee to be Heard (Sub-section 12): The AO is duty-bound not to use any material gathered during inquiry, audit, or valuation against the assessee without first affording him an opportunity of being heard. This ensures adherence to the principles of natural justice. For the assessee, it creates a right to explain, contest, or rebut such material before it is relied upon for assessment purposes. In brief, before using any material collected through inquiry, audit, or valuation against the assessee, the AO must give the assessee a chance to explain or object . 9. Definition (Sub-section 13): The term “cost accountant” is defined by reference to the Cost and Works Accountants Act, 1959. The liability of the AO here is to ensure that only qualified professionals are nominated for valuation purposes. The assessee, correspondingly, must comply with directions of such recognised professionals in furnishing information or access required for valuation. In brief, “Cost Accountant” means a cost accountant under the Cost and Works Accountants Act, 1959, holding a valid certificate of practice. 10. Summary for Taxpayer i. AO can call for returns, accounts, and asset statements if needed. Certain safeguards exist: prior approvals, time limits, and right to be heard. If accounts are complex or doubtful, AO can order a special audit or inventory valuation at Government cost. Assessee is not burdened with audit cost but must comply with timelines. This ensures fairness and transparency in assessment proceedings. The AO needs prior approval of the Joint Commissioner before asking for a statement of all assets and liabilities outside the books. AO cannot demand records older than 3 years from the relevant tax year. The notice under 268(1)(a) can also be issued by a prescribed income-tax authority . This applies even if the assessee’s accounts are already audited under some other law. AO can extend the period for good reason, but the total period (original + extension) cannot exceed 6 months from the end of the month when the direction was issued. Presuming non-compliance from the appellant notice u/s 148 was issued by ld. AO on 29-03-20xx. It is claimed by ld. AO that this notice was sent by speed post as well as email at the email id of ABCDEFG@yahoo.com. It is further mentioned by the ld. title: Income tax Q and A-16
content: Income tax Q and A-16 Section 54/54F -6 Q51. Whether the assessee is entitled to exemption under Section 54F when only part consideration was paid for purchase of a flat and the sale deed had not been executed? Ans. The Tribunal noted that the assessee later produced additional evidence: A share certificate from the Co-operative Housing Society showing ownership, A seller’s ledger account confirming that the full purchase consideration had been paid, and A letter of possession from the seller. Since these crucial documents had not been considered by the AO or CIT(A), the Tribunal held that the matter required fresh examination. Accordingly, it remanded the issue back to the AO for de novo adjudication , setting aside the earlier disallowance of Section 54F claim. The Tribunal’s reasoning rests on the principle that exemption under Section 54F depends on whether the assessee has actually purchased a residential property within the stipulated period. The AO’s objection was that merely entering into an agreement to sell and paying partial consideration does not amount to “purchase,” especially when possession was conditional upon full payment. However, the assessee substantiated ownership by producing additional evidence: the share certificate issued by the housing society, proof in the seller’s ledger that the entire consideration was ultimately paid, and a possession letter. These documents were material to establish both ownership and payment compliance. Since such evidence was not evaluated by the lower authorities, denying the exemption outright would amount to miscarriage of justice. The Tribunal emphasized the need to balance technical compliance with substantive justice, particularly when evidence is available to support the taxpayer’s claim. Thus, instead of deciding conclusively, it remanded the matter to the AO for fresh adjudication, directing that all material must be duly considered and the assessee be given fair opportunity to explain. This reflects the judiciary’s approach of ensuring natural justice in tax matters rather than adhering to a rigid technicality. Madan Mohan Mishra v. ITO [2024] 160 taxmann.com 42 (Mumbai Trib.) Q52. Is an assessee entitled to exemption under Section 54 when the flat was booked under an apartment buyer agreement prior to the sale, but both sale and possession of the flat were completed within three years from the sale of the original house? Ans. The Court upheld the Tribunal’s view that the assessee was entitled to Section 54 relief. It held that once the sale and possession of the under-construction flat were completed within three years from the date of sale of the old house , the statutory conditions stood satisfied. The Court further noted that this interpretation was consistent with its earlier judgment in Pr. CIT v. Akshay Sobti [2020] 423 ITR 321 (Delhi). Accordingly, the appeal of the Revenue was dismissed as raising no substantial question of law. The Delhi High Court emphasized that Section 54 is a beneficial provision intended to grant relief to taxpayers who reinvest their long-term capital gains into residential property. The Revenue’s technical objection—that the apartment buyer agreement predated the sale of the original house—was rejected because the law allows not only “purchase” within one year before or two years after, but also “construction” within three years of the sale. In this case, although the agreement was earlier, the critical event was the completion of sale and possession of the flat, which occurred within three years. Relying on its own precedent in Akshay Sobti , the Court reiterated that acquisition of a flat through a builder under a buyer’s agreement amounts to “construction,” not mere “purchase.” Therefore, once the assessee had taken possession and the transaction was completed within the permissible period, the exemption could not be denied. The Court also reminded that beneficial provisions must be interpreted liberally once the eligibility criteria are met. Since the Tribunal’s view aligned with binding precedent, the High Court held there was no “substantial question of law” for further interference. Hence, the assessee’s claim under Section 54 was upheld. CIT (IT) v. Reema Chawla [2024] 161 taxmann.com 422 (Delhi) Q53. Whether the assessee, who received 15 residential apartment units under a Joint Development Agreement (JDA), could claim exemption under Section 54F in respect of all units, or whether the benefit was confined only to one residential unit as contended by the Assessing Officer? Ans. The Tribunal held that the amendment made by the Finance (No. 2) Act, 2014—substituting the word “a” with “one” residential house—was prospective , applicable only from 01.04.2015. For earlier years, the expression “a residential house” could include multiple units. Relying on Karnataka High Court and Madras High Court precedents, the Tribunal decided in favour of the assessee , confirming that he was entitled to Section 54F exemption for all 15 units received under the JDA. The Tribunal’s reasoning was grounded in statutory interpretation and judicial precedent. Prior to 01.04.2015, Section 54F used the expression “a residential house.” Courts, including the Karnataka High Court in CIT v. Rukminiamma and D. Ananda Basappa , had consistently interpreted this phrase to include multiple units, as the indefinite article “a” could mean singular or plural depending on the context. The Finance (No. 2) Act, 2014 amended the provision by replacing “a” with “one,” thereby restricting the exemption to a single residential unit. However, this amendment was explicitly made prospective . Therefore, for AY 2008-09, when the assessee received 15 apartments under a JDA, he could legitimately claim exemption on all the units. The Tribunal also drew support from the Madras High Court in CIT v. V.R. Karpagam , which clarified that principles under Section 54 apply pari passu to Section 54F. By affirming that beneficial provisions must be construed liberally when the assessee meets the eligibility criteria, the Tribunal rejected the Revenue’s restrictive interpretation. Consequently, the appeal of the Revenue was dismissed, and the assessee’s right to claim exemption for all 15 units was upheld. ACIT v. Narayanappa Ramanna [2024] 162 taxmann.com 739 (Bang. Trib.) Q54. Whether exemption under Section 54F can be claimed on capital gains arising from the sale of a depreciable asset (office premises) where Section 50 deems the gain to be short-term, even though the property was held for more than 36 months? Ans. The Tribunal held that the deeming fiction of Section 50 is limited to the computation and taxability of capital gains as short-term, but it does not alter the character of the underlying asset, which remained a long-term capital asset since it was held for more than 36 months. Therefore, exemption under Section 54F could be claimed. However, as depreciation had been claimed, Section 41(2) (business income on recaptured depreciation) also applied. The Tribunal remanded the matter to the AO to recompute income under Sections 41(2) and 50, and then allow Section 54F exemption if all other conditions were satisfied. The Tribunal clarified an important interpretative point: Section 50 creates only a limited deeming fiction. It requires that capital gains on sale of depreciable assets be taxed as short-term capital gains, regardless of the holding period. However, this fiction does not convert the nature of the asset itself from long-term to short-term. In the present case, the assessee’s office property had been held for more than 36 months, and thus continued to be a long-term capital asset . Therefore, even though the gain was taxed as short-term due to Section 50, the assessee could still avail the benefit of Section 54F, which applies to transfers of long-term assets. This interpretation is consistent with precedents such as CIT v. Ace Builders Pvt. Ltd. (Bom HC) and CIT v. V.S. Dempo Co. Ltd. (SC), which held that deeming provisions must be applied strictly and only for the purpose for which they are enacted. The Tribunal also pointed out that while the AO was bound by the assessee’s omission in the original return, appellate authorities are not so restricted and can entertain additional claims. Accordingly, the case was remanded for fresh computation, with directions that Section 54F exemption be granted if other statutory conditions were met. Sonia Pathak Khanna v. ITO [2024] 164 taxmann.com 607 (Mumbai - Trib.) Q55. Whether an assessee can claim exemption under Section 54F when the construction of a new residential house was completed more than seven years after the transfer of the original asset, citing developer disputes as a reason for delay? Ans. The Tribunal rejected the claim. It held that Section 54F requires the assessee to purchase a house within two years or construct one within three years from the date of transfer. Since construction was completed in 2023—over seven years later—the statutory condition was not met. The Tribunal further observed that the developer’s disputes arose only in 2021, which was already beyond the three-year window, and the assessee failed to prove that any steps were taken to ensure timely completion. Thus, exemption under Section 54F was denied . The Tribunal’s decision rests on the strict construction of time-bound conditions in Section 54F. This section provides a tax benefit only when the assessee reinvests capital gains into residential property within the specific period prescribed: purchase within two years or construction within three years of transfer. In this case, the transfer under the JDA took place in May 2016, so the deadline for completion was May 2019. However, construction was completed only in November 2023, i.e., more than four years after the statutory period had lapsed. The assessee argued that litigation between the developer’s partners caused the delay, but the Tribunal noted that such disputes began only in October 2021—well after the statutory period had already expired. Moreover, the assessee failed to demonstrate due diligence or efforts to enforce her contractual rights during the seven-year delay. The Tribunal emphasized that beneficial provisions like Section 54F, while liberal in intent, cannot override explicit statutory timelines. Thus, since both the purchase and construction requirements were not met within the permissible period, the exemption could not be granted. The decision reinforces the principle that procedural timelines under tax exemptions are mandatory and not subject to equitable relaxation. Smt. Lekha Reddy Mettu v. ACIT [2024] 163 taxmann.com 303 (Hyd. Trib.) Q56. For claiming exemption under Section 54, should the relevant date be the agreement to purchase an under-construction flat (21-06-2014) or the date of possession (16-11-2015)? Ans. The Tribunal held that the relevant date is the date of possession of the new residential property, not the date of the agreement. Since possession was received on 16-11-2015—well within two years of the sale of the original property (22-07-2015)—the assessee’s claim under Section 54 was valid. Accordingly, the Tribunal allowed the exemption. The Tribunal emphasized the principle that Section 54, being a beneficial provision , must be interpreted liberally to promote reinvestment in housing. At the time of entering into the purchase agreement (21-06-2014), the property was still under construction and thus could not be regarded as a “residential house.” A residential property comes into existence only once the builder obtains the occupancy certificate and hands over possession. Judicial precedents, such as CIT v. Beena K. Jain (Bom HC), have established that the date of possession and completion is the decisive point for Section 54 eligibility, not the earlier booking date. Applying this reasoning, the Tribunal concluded that since possession and occupancy certificate were both secured in 2015, the assessee satisfied the statutory requirement of purchasing a new property within two years of selling the old one. The Assessing Officer’s narrow interpretation—treating the agreement date as final—was rejected, as it ignored the substance of the transaction. Thus, the Tribunal held that the assessee rightfully deserved the exemption, reinforcing that the beneficial nature of Section 54 should not be frustrated by rigid technicalities. Prateek Rajendra Kapadia v. ITO [2024] 164 taxmann.com 762 (Mumbai - Trib.) Q57. For the purpose of Section 54, should the date of purchase be taken as the agreement date (2009) or the possession date (2011) when the flat became inhabitable? Ans. The Tribunal ruled in favour of the assessee. It held that in the case of under-construction flats, the relevant date of purchase is the date of possession/handing over of the completed flat , not the date of the initial purchase agreement. Therefore, the assessee was entitled to claim exemption under Section 54. The Tribunal emphasized that Section 54 is a beneficial provision designed to encourage reinvestment of capital gains into residential housing. When an assessee enters into an agreement for an under-construction property, he merely acquires a right to purchase ; the actual “purchase” is completed only when the property is ready for occupation and possession is handed over. In this case, although the agreement was signed in July 2009, the flat was completed and possession was given on 02-02-2011—just days before the sale of the old property on 10-02-2011. Judicial precedents, such as CIT v. Beena K. Jain (Bom HC), Pr. CIT v. Akshay Sobti (Delhi HC), and Bastimal K. Jain v. ITO (Mum Trib.), all establish that possession and completion of construction are the decisive factors. The Tribunal also noted that in computing capital gains, even the AO had considered allotment/possession dates as relevant for acquisition. Hence, consistency required adopting possession date for Section 54 as well. Since possession was obtained within the statutory window, the assessee satisfied the condition. Thus, exemption under Section 54 was rightly allowable, reaffirming the principle that substance of the transaction prevails over mere technicalities. Sunil Amritlal Shah v. ITO [2024] 162 taxmann.com 676 (Mumbai - Trib.) Q58. Can exemption under Section 54 be denied solely on the technical ground that the assessee did not file a return of income, even though all statutory conditions for exemption were substantively fulfilled? Ans. The Tribunal held that when substantive conditions for Section 54 are satisfied and documentary evidence supports the claim, the benefit cannot be denied on mere technicalities like non-filing of return. The Assessing Officer was directed to recompute income after allowing Section 54 exemption. The Tribunal emphasized that tax exemptions under Section 54 flow from substantive statutory compliance , not procedural lapses. In this case, the assessee had indeed sold a long-term residential property and reinvested the gains into another residential house within the permissible time. The Assessing Officer himself admitted in his remand report that all conditions of Section 54 were met. The only objection was that the assessee had not filed a return claiming the exemption. The Tribunal rejected this reasoning, noting that substantive law confers the benefit once eligibility conditions are fulfilled; it cannot be taken away on technical grounds. Reference was made to Article 265 of the Constitution , which mandates that no tax shall be levied or collected except by authority of law. Since the assessee was not liable to tax after reinvestment, levying tax merely because of non-filing of return would violate this constitutional safeguard. The Tribunal also relied on precedents such as Smt. Sneh Lata Jain v. CIT (J&K HC) and clarified that while an Assessing Officer may be constrained by procedural bars (per Goetze India Ltd. ), appellate authorities like the Tribunal are not so limited. Accordingly, the claim under Section 54 was allowed. Seema Heera v. ACIT [2024] 164 taxmann.com 329 / [2024] 207 ITD 788 (Mumbai - Trib.) Q59. Whether ownership of a farm property with a bungalow and residential facilities disqualifies the assessee from claiming deduction under Section 54F, even if the assessee claims it was used for agricultural or commercial purposes? Ans. The Tribunal held against the assessee , deciding that the Vishubaug farm property was indeed a residential house. It observed that the bungalow on the farm was habitable, furnished, and used for residential purposes. Further, since the entire investment in the property came from the assessee’s own funds, joint registration with family members did not alter ownership. Thus, as the assessee already owned two residential properties, he was not eligible for deduction under Section 54F. The Tribunal’s reasoning emphasized the restrictive conditions under Section 54F. The proviso to Section 54F bars exemption if, on the date of transfer of the original asset, the assessee owns more than one residential house other than the new property purchased. In this case, evidence from inspection reports and photographs established that the Vishubaug property had a fully developed bungalow, surrounded by verandahs, furnished with household items, and capable of residential use. Although the assessee argued that the property was for agricultural and dairy purposes, he failed to declare any agricultural income in his tax returns. The Tribunal also referred to the Orissa High Court’s ruling in State of Orissa v. Ramchandra Chaudhary (1962) 46 ITR 246 , holding that dairy farming is not agricultural income, thereby weakening the assessee’s claim. Moreover, joint registration of property with wife and daughter was disregarded, since the assessee had funded the entire investment; mere co-registration could not shield him from the statutory bar. Accepting such arguments, the Tribunal observed, would open a loophole for tax avoidance. Therefore, since the assessee owned more than one residential property at the relevant time, his claim under Section 54F was rightly denied. Atul Govindji Shroff v. DCIT [2024] 166 taxmann.com 246 (Ahmedabad - Trib.) Q60. Can exemption under Section 54 be denied if the assessee uses other funds (not the exact sale consideration) for constructing a new house, and files a return under section 139(4) instead of section 139(1)? Ans. The Tribunal ruled in favour of the assessee . It held that Section 54 does not mandate that only the sale proceeds must be used; the use of other funds is also valid so long as a residential house is purchased/constructed within the statutory timelines. Further, investments made before filing a return under section 139(4) amount to sufficient compliance. Therefore, the assessee was eligible for deduction under Section 54. The Tribunal emphasized the beneficial nature of Section 54, which aims to encourage reinvestment of capital gains into housing. It clarified that the provision requires the assessee to “purchase within one year before or two years after” or “construct within three years” a residential house. There is no stipulation that the very same sale proceeds must be used; even borrowed funds or other resources can be applied. Thus, if the cost of the new house exceeds the capital gains, exemption is allowable up to the amount of gains. In this case, although some payments were made before the sale, construction was completed within three years, fulfilling statutory intent. Regarding the delay in filing return, the Tribunal relied on decisions such as Manilal Dasbhai Makwana v. ITO and C. Aryama Sundaram v. CIT , holding that compliance with section 54(2) is met if capital gains are invested before filing the return under section 139(4). The requirement to deposit into the Capital Gains Account Scheme applies only when funds remain unutilized. Since here the funds were already invested, no such deposit was necessary. Thus, by adopting a liberal interpretation consistent with legislative intent, the Tribunal upheld the assessee’s claim under Section 54. Jignesh Jaysukhlal Ghiya v.
