content: Income Tax Q and A -15 Section 54/54F-5 Q41. For the purpose of exemption under Section 54 of the Income-tax Act, 1961, should the date of possession of a newly constructed flat be treated as the date of purchase, rather than the earlier agreement date? Ans. The Tribunal ruled in favour of the assessee , holding that: The date of possession of the new flat (24-12-2018) is the relevant date of purchase for the purpose of Section 54, not merely the agreement date. At the time of agreement in 2016, the flat was not yet constructed; the assessee only had a right to acquire it in future. Relying on CIT v. Beena K. Jain (Bom. HC), the Tribunal clarified that acquisition is complete only when the property is ready, full consideration is paid, and possession is handed over. Since possession was within two months of selling the old bungalow (23-10-2018), the assessee satisfied Section 54 conditions and was entitled to exemption. The Tribunal highlighted that the substance of the transaction is crucial in interpreting Section 54. The object of the provision is to grant relief where capital gains are reinvested in residential property, not to deny exemption on technicalities. At the time of agreement in December 2016, the flat was under construction and no habitable property existed. Thus, the assessee had only acquired a contractual right, not a residential house. The Tribunal relied on the Bombay High Court’s ruling in CIT v. Beena K. Jain (217 ITR 363) , which held that the relevant date for Section 54 is when the assessee pays consideration and receives possession of a completed flat. Similarly, in Ayushi Patni v. DCIT , the Pune Tribunal had treated possession date as decisive. Applying these precedents, the Tribunal ruled that the flat was effectively “purchased” only on 24-12-2018, when the builder handed over possession, which was well within the two-year statutory limit from the sale of the old house. Thus, the exemption under Section 54 was rightly allowable. This approach ensures that the beneficial provision achieves its legislative intent of encouraging housing reinvestment and avoids unjust denial of relief based on premature agreement dates. Sanjay Vasant Jumde v. ITO [2023] 148 taxmann.com 34 / [2023] 200 ITD 285 (Pune - Trib.) Q42. Does Section 54F relief depend on completion/possession of the house within three years, or on investment of capital gains within the prescribed period? Ans. The Tribunal ruled in favour of the assessee , holding that: Section 54F requires that the capital gains be invested in purchase or construction within the prescribed time, not that construction must be fully completed or possession handed over. In this case, payments for purchase of property and construction were duly made within the time limit, and that too from the Capital Gains Account. Hence, denial of exemption merely on the ground that construction was incomplete was without merit. The assessee was entitled to deduction under Section 54F. The Tribunal emphasized the beneficial nature of Section 54F, which aims to incentivize reinvestment of capital gains into housing. It rejected the Commissioner (Appeals)’s reasoning that exemption could be denied solely because construction was incomplete or possession was not given within three years. Judicial precedents, including Smt. Shashi Verma v. CIT (MP HC) and Pr. CIT v. C. Gopalaswamy (Kar. HC), have clarified that what matters is substantial investment within the statutory period, not completion. The Tribunal noted that the assessee had deposited gains in the Capital Gains Account Scheme and used the funds for purchasing property and construction. These facts were undisputed, and even acknowledged by the Commissioner (Appeals). By contrast, denying exemption for lack of completion would unfairly penalize taxpayers for delays often outside their control, such as those caused by builders or authorities. Accordingly, the Tribunal quashed the disallowance and held that Section 54F relief depends on timely appropriation of funds , not on physical completion or possession. This interpretation aligns with the object of the law—promoting housing investment—while ensuring fairness to assessees. Subramanian Swaminathan v. ACIT [2023] 152 taxmann.com 72 / [2023] 201 ITD 487 (Delhi - Trib.) Q43. Should unutilized funds lying in the Capital Gains Account Scheme be taxed once the statutory three-year period expires, even when delay in construction is solely due to the builder and litigation is pending before the High Court? Ans. The Tribunal ruled in favour of the assessee , holding that: The assessee had already paid a substantial portion (about 64%) of the purchase price, and the balance remained in the Capital Gains Account Scheme. Since construction was halted by the builder and the matter was pending before the High Court, it was a case of impossibility of performance beyond the assessee’s control. Therefore, the unutilized funds could not be forced into taxation immediately after three years. The limitation period for utilization stands extended until resolution of the dispute, and taxation may arise only if the assessee later withdraws or misuses the funds. The Tribunal emphasized that Section 54F is a beneficial provision , meant to provide relief to taxpayers who reinvest their gains in residential housing. It cannot be interpreted harshly where genuine investment intent exists but external circumstances prevent completion. In this case, the assessee had invested about 64% of the purchase price and kept the remaining funds in the Capital Gains Account Scheme, demonstrating a clear intention to reinvest. The difficulty arose solely because the builder stopped construction and failed to deliver possession, forcing the assessee to file a suit before the High Court. The Tribunal observed that taxing the unutilized amount under these circumstances would cause undue hardship , as the assessee was prevented from completing the investment due to factors beyond his control. Relying on precedents like Pr. CIT v. C. Gopalaswamy (Kar. HC), it held that completion or possession is not essential if substantial investment is made. Accordingly, the Tribunal treated the case as one of impossibility of performance and extended the time for utilization until the dispute was resolved. This ensures fairness while preserving the legislative intent of Section 54F—to encourage housing investment, not penalize taxpayers for delays caused by builders. Dhananjay Madhukar Naik v. ITO [2023] 154 taxmann.com 540 / [2023] 203 ITD 30 (Mumbai - Trib.) Q44. Can exemption under Section 54 be allowed on capital gains from sale of a plot of land, or should the correct provision be Section 54F? Ans. The Tribunal ruled in favour of the Revenue , holding that: Exemption under Section 54 applies only to capital gains from transfer of a residential house property (building or land appurtenant thereto). Since the assessee sold a plot of land , Section 54 relief was wrongly allowed by the AO. The PCIT correctly exercised revisionary jurisdiction under Section 263, directing the AO to re-examine the assessee’s eligibility under Section 54F. The assessee’s plea that no prejudice was caused to the Revenue as the exemption quantum was the same under Section 54F could not be accepted, since this required verification. Hence, the revision order was upheld. The Tribunal emphasized that Section 54 and Section 54F operate in distinct spheres . Section 54 applies only when capital gains arise from the transfer of a residential house property , while Section 54F applies when the capital gains arise from transfer of any long-term capital asset other than a residential house . In this case, the asset sold was a plot of land , and therefore exemption under Section 54 was clearly not applicable. The Assessing Officer erred in granting Section 54 relief, and the Principal Commissioner was justified in invoking Section 263 as the assessment order was both erroneous and prejudicial to the interests of Revenue . The assessee’s argument—that even under Section 54F the exemption quantum would have been the same—was rejected, as this required verification of compliance with conditions under Section 54F, such as proportionality rules and restrictions on owning multiple houses. The Tribunal reiterated that procedural correctness in applying the right provision is essential, even if the Revenue suffers no immediate loss. Beneficial provisions like Section 54F must indeed be liberally construed, but only when the statutory preconditions are met. Accordingly, the revision order was upheld, and the assessee’s appeal dismissed. Smt. Janki Kishan Hingorani v. PCIT [2024] 158 taxmann.com 3 (Rajkot - Trib.) Q45. Whether an assessee who mistakenly claims exemption under Section 54 instead of Section 54F can correct the section during assessment without filing a revised return, when the substantive conditions for exemption are satisfied? Ans. The Tribunal ruled in favour of the assessee , holding that: This was not a case of a new claim but a bona fide error of quoting the wrong section . The assessee had in substance claimed exemption on reinvestment of capital gains in residential property, which was valid under Section 54F. A correction of the section at the assessment stage is permissible and qualitatively different from making an entirely fresh claim. Therefore, the assessee was entitled to exemption under Section 54F without filing a revised return. The Tribunal highlighted that the Income-tax Act must be applied with a substantive rather than hyper-technical approach . The object of Sections 54 and 54F is to exempt capital gains when reinvested into residential housing. In this case, the assessee had surrendered tenancy rights (a long-term capital asset other than a residential house), which qualified for Section 54F and not Section 54. However, by mistake, the return reflected a claim under Section 54. The Assessing Officer rejected the claim citing Goetz (India) Ltd. v. CIT (SC), which held that fresh claims cannot be entertained without a revised return. The Tribunal distinguished that ruling, noting that Goetz applied only when a completely new claim was sought to be introduced during assessment. Here, the assessee’s claim was already made, but under the wrong section. Correcting the section was only a technical rectification of a valid claim, not the introduction of a new one. The Tribunal approved the CIT(A)’s reasoning that substance should prevail over form. Since the assessee had invested more than the entire consideration in a new flat, the exemption conditions under Section 54F were fully satisfied. Hence, denial of relief would defeat the beneficial purpose of the provision. ITO (Intl. Taxation) v. Armine Hamied Khan [2022] 142 taxmann.com 14 / [2022] 197 ITD 110 (Mumbai - Trib.) Q46. Does Section 54 relief require the new property to be purchased exclusively in the assessee’s own name, or is investment in the name of a spouse sufficient? Ans. The Tribunal ruled in favour of the assessee , holding that: The sale proceeds were duly invested in the purchase of a new house, and this was supported by bank statements and builder receipts. The registry in the spouse’s name was only for convenience since the assessee was abroad due to Covid-related restrictions. Relying on Delhi High Court rulings ( CIT v. Kamal Wahal and CIT v. Ravinder Kumar Arora ), the Tribunal held that purchase in the spouse’s name still qualifies for Section 54 relief. Thus, the exemption under Section 54 was allowed. The Tribunal emphasized that Sections 54 and 54F are beneficial provisions aimed at promoting reinvestment of capital gains into residential housing. Their interpretation should be purposive and liberal rather than restrictive. The Assessing Officer had adopted a narrow view by insisting that the new property must be registered exclusively in the assessee’s name. However, the Tribunal noted that neither Section 54 nor Section 54F explicitly mandates this. Judicial precedents, particularly from the Delhi High Court in Kamal Wahal and Ravinder Kumar Arora , have consistently held that where an assessee invests the sale proceeds in a house purchased in the spouse’s name, exemption cannot be denied. The rationale is that what matters is the source of funds and the fact of reinvestment, not the technicality of in whose name the sale deed stands. In this case, the assessee had clearly used her sale proceeds to acquire the new property, and the registry in her spouse’s name occurred only because she could not travel to India during Covid restrictions. Denying relief in such circumstances would defeat the legislative intent. Therefore, the Tribunal rightly upheld the assessee’s eligibility for exemption under Section 54. Simran Bagga v. ACIT [2024] 158 taxmann.com 265 / [2024] 205 ITD 100 (Delhi - Trib.) Q47. Can an assessment allowing deduction under Section 54F be reopened under Sections 147/148 without any new tangible material, when all facts were already disclosed during the original scrutiny—amounting only to a change of opinion? Ans. The Bombay High Court ruled in favour of the assessee , holding that: During the original scrutiny, the Assessing Officer had specifically inquired about immovable property transactions, and the assessee had disclosed all details, including the Section 54F claim. The assessment order was passed after considering this material, hence reopening the case later amounted to a mere change of opinion , which is impermissible. Since no failure of disclosure by the assessee was established and no fresh tangible material was brought on record, the reopening notice and subsequent reassessment order were invalid. Accordingly, the notices, reassessment order, and penalty proceedings were quashed. The Court emphasized that the first proviso to Section 147 prohibits reopening of assessments after four years unless there is failure by the assessee to disclose fully and truly all material facts. In this case, the assessee had, in response to notices during scrutiny, furnished complete details of his property sales, computation of capital gains, and supporting documents for exemption under Section 54F. The AO, having examined these, passed an assessment order allowing the deduction. The Court reiterated that reopening cannot be used as a tool to review or change an earlier opinion of the AO, citing CIT v. Kelvinator of India Ltd. (SC). A mere oversight by the AO in appreciating the same material does not constitute escapement of income due to the assessee’s failure. Moreover, the Revenue failed to provide recorded reasons for reopening to the assessee, violating the principles laid down in GKN Driveshafts (India) Ltd. v. ITO (SC). Thus, the reopening lacked jurisdictional foundation and was quashed. The judgment safeguards taxpayers from repeated reassessments based only on shifting opinions of tax authorities, reinforcing the principle of finality and certainty in assessments under Section 54F. Ashraf Chitalwala v. DCIT [2023] 155 taxmann.com 137 / [2024] 461 ITR 235 (Bombay HC) Q48. Does joint ownership of more than one residential property disentitle an assessee from claiming exemption under Section 54F of the Income-tax Act, 1961? Ans. The Tribunal ruled in favour of the assessee , holding that: Joint ownership of residential property cannot be equated with absolute ownership . Unless the assessee is the exclusive owner of more than one residential house, Section 54F exemption cannot be denied. Since there was no contrary binding decision from the jurisdictional High Court, the Tribunal followed the favourable rulings of the Madras High Court ( Dr. Smt. P.K. Vasanthi Rangarajan v. CIT ) and coordinate benches. Therefore, the assessee’s claim under Section 54F was allowed. The Tribunal emphasized that the proviso to Section 54F intends to prevent relief where an assessee already owns multiple residential houses, but this condition applies only to full ownership . A co-owner merely holds a fractional interest, which does not amount to ownership of a “residential house” in the sense contemplated by the proviso. Judicial precedents, including Dr. Smt. P.K. Vasanthi Rangarajan (Madras HC) and several ITAT rulings, have consistently held that joint ownership does not disentitle a taxpayer from claiming Section 54F relief. In this case, the assessee had sold agricultural land and deposited the capital gains in the Capital Gains Account Scheme before investing in a new flat, thereby satisfying the core requirements of Section 54F. The Revenue’s reliance on the Karnataka High Court ruling in M.J. Siwani v. CIT was rejected because the Supreme Court had dismissed the SLP without laying down binding law, and more favourable interpretations existed. Following the principle laid down in CIT v. Vegetable Products Ltd. (SC), where two interpretations are possible, the one beneficial to the assessee must prevail. Thus, the Tribunal rightly allowed the deduction, reinforcing that beneficial provisions like Section 54F must be construed liberally to fulfil their purpose. Shweta Singh v. ITO [2024] 161 taxmann.com 302 (Mumbai - Trib.) Q49. Is exemption under Section 54F available to an assessee for investment in a residential house outside India (USA) prior to the Finance (No. 2) Act, 2014 amendment restricting such investment to properties situated ‘in India’? Ans. The Bombay High Court ruled in favour of the assessee , holding that: The amendment requiring investment “in India” is prospective from 1-4-2015. For AY 2014-15, the unamended Section 54F applied, which simply required investment in “a residential house” without geographic restriction. Since the assessee had duly invested the sale proceeds in a house in the USA within the prescribed period, he satisfied the statutory conditions and was entitled to exemption. The Revenue’s reliance on Section 5(2) and its claim that the amendment was clarificatory and retrospective was rejected. The Court emphasized that statutory amendments are to be treated as prospective unless expressly or necessarily retrospective. Before the Finance (No. 2) Act, 2014, Section 54F only required that capital gains be invested in “a residential house,” with no condition restricting such house to India. By inserting the words “in India” w.e.f. 1-4-2015, Parliament imposed a new substantive condition. Since the pre-amended law was neither vague nor ambiguous, the amendment could not be treated as clarificatory. The Court also noted that Section 5(2), which speaks of income accruing or arising “in India,” cannot override the specific language of Section 54F. The scheme of exemption provisions shows that the focus is on reinvestment of gains into residential housing, and prior to 2015 this relief extended even to property purchased abroad. The legislative intent of the amendment was to restrict such benefits going forward, not retrospectively. Accordingly, as the assessee had sold a residential flat in India and invested the capital gains in a residential flat in the USA within the statutory time limit, he had complied with Section 54F as it stood. The denial of exemption was therefore unjustified, and the assessee’s claim was allowed. Hemant Dinkar Kandlur v. CIT (International Taxation) [2023] 155 taxmann.com 493 / [2024] 462 ITR 67 (Bombay HC) Q50. Can exemption under Section 54F be granted when the new residential property is registered in the names of the assessee’s parents, but the investment is entirely made from the assessee’s own funds and the property is later gifted back to him? Ans. The Tribunal ruled in favour of the assessee , holding that: The investments for the new property were made by the assessee from his own bank account. The property was registered in his parents’ names only because the assessee was abroad at the time of registration. Subsequently, the property was gifted back to the assessee by his parents, confirming his ownership. Relying on purposive interpretation and precedents like CIT v. Kamal Wahal , the Tribunal upheld the CIT(A)’s decision allowing exemption under Section 54F. The Tribunal applied the rule of purposive construction , emphasizing that Section 54F is a beneficial provision aimed at encouraging reinvestment of capital gains in residential housing. Its object would be defeated if genuine investments are denied relief merely due to technicalities such as whose name appears on the purchase deed. What matters is the source of funds and the assessee’s beneficial ownership, not the formality of registration. In this case, the assessee sold a residential house and invested the entire sale proceeds in buying another property. The payments were made directly from his bank account, establishing that he was the real investor. The property was registered in his parents’ names only because of his absence from India, a practical necessity. Later, his parents formally gifted the property back to him, confirming the arrangement. Courts, including the Delhi High Court in CIT v. Kamal Wahal and ACIT v. Suresh Verma , have consistently held that exemption cannot be denied if the purchase is made in the name of a spouse or close family member, provided the funds belong to the assessee. Following this principle, the Tribunal allowed the exemption under Section 54F, ensuring the legislative intent was fulfilled. Rajiv Ghai v. ACIT [2024] 160 taxmann.com 509 / [2024] 109 ITR(T) 439 (Delhi - Trib.) The date of possession of the new flat (24-12-2018) is the relevant date of purchase for the purpose of Section 54, not merely the agreement date. At the time of agreement in 2016, the flat was not yet constructed; the assessee only had a right to acquire it in future. Relying on CIT v. Beena K. Jain (Bom. HC), the Tribunal clarified that acquisition is complete only when the property is ready, full consideration is paid, and possession is handed over. Since possession was within two months of selling the old bungalow (23-10-2018), the assessee satisfied Section 54 conditions and was entitled to exemption. Section 54F requires that the capital gains be invested in purchase or construction within the prescribed time, not that construction must be fully completed or possession handed over. In this case, payments for purchase of property and construction were duly made within the time limit, and that too from the Capital Gains Account. Hence, denial of exemption merely on the ground that construction was incomplete was without merit. The assessee was entitled to deduction under Section 54F. The assessee had already paid a substantial portion (about 64%) of the purchase price, and the balance remained in the Capital Gains Account Scheme. Since construction was halted by the builder and the matter was pending before the High Court, it was a case of impossibility of performance beyond the assessee’s control. Therefore, the unutilized funds could not be forced into taxation immediately after three years. The limitation period for utilization stands extended until resolution of the dispute, and taxation may arise only if the assessee later withdraws or misuses the funds. Exemption under Section 54 applies only to capital gains from transfer of a residential house property (building or land appurtenant thereto). Since the assessee sold a plot of land , Section 54 relief was wrongly allowed by the AO. The PCIT correctly exercised revisionary jurisdiction under Section 263, directing the AO to re-examine the assessee’s eligibility under Section 54F. The assessee’s plea that no prejudice was caused to the Revenue as the exemption quantum was the same under Section 54F could not be accepted, since this required verification. Hence, the revision order was upheld. This was not a case of a new claim but a bona fide error of quoting the wrong section . The assessee had in substance claimed exemption on reinvestment of capital gains in residential property, which was valid under Section 54F. A correction of the section at the assessment stage is permissible and qualitatively different from making an entirely fresh claim. Therefore, the assessee was entitled to exemption under Section 54F without filing a revised return. The sale proceeds were duly invested in the purchase of a new house, and this was supported by bank statements and builder receipts. The registry in the spouse’s name was only for convenience since the assessee was abroad due to Covid-related restrictions. Relying on Delhi High Court rulings ( CIT v. Kamal Wahal and CIT v. Ravinder Kumar Arora ), the Tribunal held that purchase in the spouse’s name still qualifies for Section 54 relief. Thus, the exemption under Section 54 was allowed. During the original scrutiny, the Assessing Officer had specifically inquired about immovable property transactions, and the assessee had disclosed all details, including the Section 54F claim. The assessment order was passed after considering this material, hence reopening the case later amounted to a mere change of opinion , which is impermissible. Since no failure of disclosure by the assessee was established and no fresh tangible material was brought on record, the reopening notice and subsequent reassessment order were invalid. Accordingly, the notices, reassessment order, and penalty proceedings were quashed. Joint ownership of residential property cannot be equated with absolute ownership . Unless the assessee is the exclusive owner of more than one residential house, Section 54F exemption cannot be denied. Since there was no contrary binding decision from the jurisdictional High Court, the Tribunal followed the favourable rulings of the Madras High Court ( Dr. Smt. P.K. Vasanthi Rangarajan v. CIT ) and coordinate benches. Therefore, the assessee’s claim under Section 54F was allowed. The amendment requiring investment “in India” is prospective from 1-4-2015. For AY 2014-15, the unamended Section 54F applied, which simply required investment in “a residential house” without geographic restriction. Since the assessee had duly invested the sale proceeds in a house in the USA within the prescribed period, he satisfied the statutory conditions and was entitled to exemption. The Revenue’s reliance on Section 5(2) and its claim that the amendment was clarificatory and retrospective was rejected. The investments for the new property were made by the assessee from his own bank account. The property was registered in his parents’ names only because the assessee was abroad at the time of registration. Subsequently, the property was gifted back to the assessee by his parents, confirming his ownership. Relying on purposive interpretation and precedents like CIT v. Kamal Wahal , the Tribunal upheld the CIT(A)’s decision allowing exemption under Section 54F.

title: Tax News-12
content: Tax News-12 Based on case laws uploaded in August 2025 1. ITAT Ahmedabad Remands Case on Bogus Purchases for Verification of GST ITC and Genuineness of Transactions ITO v. Ramlal Manekchand HUF [2025 (8) TMI 1332 – ITAT Ahmedabad] The issue concerned additions on account of unexplained purchases under section 769C . The assessee, engaged in bullion and jewellery trading, had shown purchases worth ₹25.17 crore from five parties. The AO, based on Designated Verification Unit reports, found two suppliers working as labourers/furniture workers and three others untraceable. Purchases from the first two were treated as unexplained expenditure (₹16.13 crore net addition), while 10% profit element was added on purchases from the other three parties (₹89.41 lakh). CIT(A) deleted additions relying on invoices, ledgers, and bank entries, without addressing the adverse evidences. On appeal, the Tribunal observed that a crucial aspect—the status of GST input tax credit (ITC) on these purchases involving ₹75.51 lakh GST—was neither examined by AO nor CIT(A). Since ITC reconciliation could establish genuineness or otherwise, the Tribunal restored the matter to AO for fresh verification, including suppliers’ GST returns, bank accounts, and fund trail. 2. ITAT Ahmedabad Reduces Penalty under Section 271(1)(b) for Non-compliance with Notices Harshadkumar Bhogilal Raval v. ITO [2025 (8) TMI 1331 – ITAT Ahmedabad] The assessee challenged penalty proceedings under section 271(1)(b) for failure to comply with notices issued under section 142(1) . The assessee had initially responded to the first notice with an adjournment request but failed to comply with two subsequent notices (31.03.2021 and 16.08.2021). He argued that non-compliance was due to the Covid-19 pandemic and cited the Supreme Court’s suo motu extension of limitation. The Tribunal observed that the SC extension applied to filing of appeals, not to compliance with assessment notices, and that the assessee adopted a casual approach by neither responding to penalty notices nor filing submissions. However, it also held that penalty under section 271(1)(b) is ₹10,000 per default , and for multiple failures, separate notices must be issued. Since AO imposed a consolidated penalty of ₹20,000 without separate initiation, the Tribunal reduced the penalty to ₹10,000. 3. ITAT Mumbai Upholds Late Fee under Section 234E for Post-2015 TDS Default Hi Techno Control System Pvt. Ltd. v. DCIT (Appeals) [2025 (8) TMI 1320 – ITAT Mumbai] The assessee challenged a levy of late filing fee for delayed filing of TDS return. Initially, the matter arose from an appeal against an alleged order under section 272A(2)(K) dated 19.02.2020. On revenue’s Miscellaneous Application, the Tribunal found that no such order existed. Instead, intimation under sections 154 and 200A/206CB dated 30.03.2017 had imposed a late fee of ₹85,200 for delay in filing TDS statement for Q3 of FY 2015-16 (AY 2016-17). The assessee relied on Bathline India Pvt. Ltd. (ITAT Delhi) and Fatehraj Singhvi (Karnataka HC), where levy of fee was held unsustainable for periods prior to 01.06.2015 , the effective date of section 200A(1)(c). However, the Tribunal noted that the present default (Oct–Dec 2015) was post-01.06.2015 , making the levy legally valid. Hence, the ITAT upheld CIT(A)’s order confirming the late fee under section 234E r.w.s. 200A , and dismissed the assessee’s appeal. 4. Bombay High Court Allows Set-off of Interest Expenditure Against Interest Income – Commencement of Business from Preparation Stage Modi Business Centre Pvt. Ltd. v. DCIT [2025 (8) TMI 1285 – Bombay HC] The issue was whether interest paid on Citibank loans could be set off against interest income earned by advancing part of those borrowed funds to sister concerns in AY 1992-93. The Assessing Officer treated the interest receipt as “income from other sources” and disallowed set-off, holding that business had not commenced. The ITAT upheld this view. The High Court disagreed, holding that for income-tax purposes, business commences not merely on actual letting but from the preparatory stage of acquiring, repairing, and furnishing property for letting. Citing Sarabhai Management Corp. (SC), the Court ruled that lending money to sister concerns was part of the assessee’s business objects under its MoA, and similar treatment had been accepted in later years (AYs 1993-94 to 1995-96). To ensure consistency, AY 1992-93 also had to be treated likewise. Accordingly, the HC set aside ITAT’s order and restored the CIT(A)’s decision allowing set-off under section 36(1)(iii) . 5. SLP Dismissed – Delay in Filing Form 10B Condonable, Filing is Directory Not Mandatory Addl./Jt./Dy./Asstt. CIT/ITO v. Shilparamam Arts Crafts and Cultural Society [2025] 177 taxmann.com 282 (SC) The Supreme Court dismissed Revenue’s SLP filed with a delay of 488 days against the Telangana High Court judgment. The assessee, a trust registered under section 12A, had filed its return of income for AY 2017-18 within time but uploaded Form 10B belatedly , though before the assessment order was passed. The High Court held that section 119(2)(b) empowers authorities to condone delay where genuine hardship is caused and does not prescribe any rigid limitation for filing such an application. Further, filing of audit report in Form 10B is only directory, not mandatory, especially when the return itself was filed on time. Since the audit report was available before completion of assessment, condonation should have been granted. The Supreme Court, noting both the delay in SLP filing and absence of merit, dismissed the petition, thereby affirming relief to the assessee. 6. Bogus LTCG from Penny Stock – Treated as Unexplained Cash Credit under Section 68 Jelly Samkit Doshi v. ITO [2025] 177 taxmann.com 78 (Ahmedabad – Trib.) The assessee claimed exemption under section 10(38) on alleged long-term capital gains from sale of shares of Kappac Pharma Ltd. The shares were acquired in cash through an off-market transaction in physical form, later dematerialised and sold at a huge price escalation. The AO, relying on investigation reports into penny stock scams, held the transaction as a pre-arranged accommodation entry to convert unaccounted money into tax-free LTCG. The assessee had no past or subsequent trading activity , limited income sources (mainly tuition fees in cash), and insufficient liquidity to justify the cash investment. The Tribunal noted suspicious gaps between purchase and transfer, cash acquisition, tainted scrip, and implausible price rise, which failed the test of human probabilities (relying on Durga Prasad More and Sumati Dayal ). Accordingly, the LTCG claim was rejected and the addition under section 68 , taxable u/s 115BBE , was upheld. 7. ITAT Delhi on AMP, Comparables, Interest on Receivables & DDT – Relief Partly Granted to Sony India (P.) Ltd. Sony India (P.) Ltd. v. ACIT [2025] 177 taxmann.com 325 (Delhi - Trib.) Multiple issues were decided across AYs 2015-16, 2017-18 & 2018-19. The Tribunal held that adjustments to Advertising, Marketing and Promotion (AMP) expenses are impermissible either through the Bright Line Test (BLT) or the so-called intensity approach , relying on Sony Ericsson Mobile and subsequent Delhi HC rulings. On comparables for advisory services , a company lacking complete public financials and functionally different was excluded. Regarding interest on delayed receivables , the TPO’s computation beyond the relevant AY (till 31-1-2021) was remanded for fresh verification. On Dividend Distribution Tax (DDT) , the assessee’s claim of DTAA benefit under the India–Netherlands treaty was rejected, as per the Mumbai Special Bench in Total Oil India (P.) Ltd. , holding DTAA does not apply to DDT unless explicitly extended. Overall, AMP and comparables issues were decided in favour of the assessee, DDT against it, and interest adjustment remanded. 8. Remand of Second Application for Registration under Section 12AB in Light of CBDT Circular No. 7/2024 Bethany Tamil Congregation Trust v. CIT (Exemption) [2025] 177 taxmann.com 183 (Pune - Trib.) The ITAT Pune dealt with the issue of rejection of a second application for registration under section 12AB. The assessee’s first application under section 12AB r.w.s. 12A(1)(ac) was rejected, and its provisional registration was also cancelled. Subsequently, the assessee filed a fresh application citing CBDT Circular No. 7/2024 dated 25-4-2024 , which had expressly provided another opportunity to trusts and institutions whose earlier applications were rejected. The Commissioner (Exemption) again rejected the application, holding that once provisional registration was cancelled, the assessee was disentitled to seek fresh registration. The Tribunal noted that the Circular’s intent was to grant a one-time relaxation, enabling re-application even where earlier registration was cancelled. Therefore, the Commissioner was not justified in summarily rejecting the second application. The matter was remanded to the Commissioner (Exemption) for fresh adjudication after affording due opportunity. Matter remanded; in favour of assessee. 9. Transfer Pricing Adjustments on Comparables, Foreign Exchange Gains, and Technical Fee Calsonic Kansei Motherson Auto Products (P.) Ltd. v. ACIT [2025] 177 taxmann.com 169 (Delhi - Trib.) The assessee, engaged in manufacturing HVAC systems and compressors for automobiles, contested TP adjustments made by the TPO for AY 2020-21. It argued for inclusion of certain comparables earlier accepted by the TPO and exclusion of those functionally dissimilar, having huge intangibles, engaged in R&D, or receiving government grants. The Tribunal directed inclusion of Gajjar Compressors, Swan Pneumatics, Emerson Climate, Frick India, NHK Spring, and others, while excluding Banco Products, PPAP Automotive, and Sansera Engineering. It further held that foreign exchange gains/losses form part of operating revenue following Delhi High Court’s ruling in B.C. Management Services (P.) Ltd. Payment of technical assistance fee to AE was justified since services were evidenced and amount was reasonable relative to turnover. On delayed receivables, Tribunal applied LIBOR +200 bps with a 60-day credit period. Overall, substantive TP additions were deleted, and appeal was decided in favour of assessee. 10. Appeal Dismissed as Withdrawn under Vivad se Vishwas Scheme Yum! Restaurants (India) (P.) Ltd. v. CIT [2025] 177 taxmann.com 360 (SC) The assessee, Yum! Restaurants (India) (P.) Ltd. , was engaged in managing franchisees of Pizza Hut and KFC in India. For AY 2001-02, it claimed deduction of accrued marketing expenditure under a franchisee incentive scheme, and also deduction of contributions made to its wholly owned subsidiary for advertisement and marketing. The AO disallowed part of these claims, which was upheld by appellate authorities and the Delhi High Court. The High Court held that the accrued marketing expenditure was not deductible in the relevant year since the scheme was notified to franchisees only later, and contributions to subsidiary were not made out of commercial expediency. On further appeal, the assessee submitted that disputes had been settled under the Direct Tax Vivad se Vishwas Scheme, 2024. The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal as withdrawn, leaving all contentions open. Thus, the matter was closed without adjudication on merits.
